data.text:
South Carolina, known for its charming southern hospitality and picturesque landscapes, has become a haven for numerous celebrities seeking a quieter, more relaxed lifestyle away from the glitz and glamor of Hollywood. In this article, we'll explore fifteen notable celebrities who have chosen to make South Carolina their home.

hash-mark15 Top Celebrities That Live in South Carolina

Darius Rucker

The renowned country singer and former Hootie & the Blowfish frontman Darius Rucker has deep roots in South Carolina. Born and raised in Charleston, Rucker has maintained his connection to the state throughout his successful music career.

Besides his musical endeavors, he actively supports local charities and events, showcasing his commitment to his South Carolina roots.

Viola Davis

Academy Award-winning actress Viola Davis, known for her powerful performances in films such as "The Help" and "Fences," has a residence in the picturesque city of Central, South Carolina.

Davis, a Juilliard School graduate, has spoken fondly about her South Carolina home's serene surroundings and how it contrasts the bustling entertainment industry.

Bill Murray

Comedic legend Bill Murray, famous for his roles in classics like "Ghostbusters" and "Groundhog Day," has a home in Charleston, South Carolina.

Known for his laid-back and approachable demeanor, Murray is often spotted around town, participating in local events and supporting community initiatives. His choice to reside in South Carolina reflects his desire for a more tranquil lifestyle.

Stephen Colbert

Late-night talk show host Stephen Colbert, who rose to fame with "The Colbert Report" and currently hosts "The Late Show," hails from Charleston, South Carolina.

Colbert has frequently expressed his love for his hometown and the state, often incorporating his Southern roots into his comedic routines. Despite his busy schedule in the world of television, Colbert maintains a connection to his South Carolina heritage.

Chris Rock

Stand-up comedian and actor Chris Rock has chosen Myrtle Beach, South Carolina's coastal city, as his home. Rock, known for his sharp wit and insightful humor, values the peaceful environment that South Carolina offers.

While he often travels for work, Rock finds solace and inspiration in the quiet retreat that his South Carolina residence provides.

Aziz Ansari

Stand-up comedian, actor, and writer Aziz Ansari, known for his roles in "Parks and Recreation" and his stand-up specials, has a home in the picturesque city of Charleston, South Carolina. Ansari has spoken about the city's charm and its unique blend of history and modernity. His decision to reside in South Carolina reflects his appreciation for the state's rich cultural heritage.

Lindsey Graham

U.S. Senator Lindsey Graham has represented South Carolina in the Senate since 2003. Born in Central, South Carolina, Graham continues to maintain strong ties to his home state. Besides his political career, Graham is known for his passion for golf and can often be found on the golf courses around the state, enjoying its mild climate and scenic beauty.

Chelsea Handler

Comedian, actress, and television host Chelsea Handler has a home on the coastal shores of Sullivan's Island, South Carolina. Handler, known for her irreverent humor and candid discussions, appreciates the tranquility and natural beauty that the state offers. Her waterfront property is a testament to the allure of South Carolina's coastal living.

Joe Riley

Former Mayor of Charleston Joseph P. Riley Jr., known as Joe Riley, served as the city's mayor for over four decades. A beloved figure in Charleston, Riley's efforts revitalized the city and earned him national recognition. Even after his retirement from politics, Riley continues to reside in Charleston, showcasing his deep love for the city he helped transform.

Hootie & the Blowfish

Apart from Darius Rucker, the other members of the famous band Hootie & the Blowfish also have ties to South Carolina. Mark Bryan, Dean Felber, and Jim "Soni" Sonefeld, the band's guitarist, bassist, and drummer, respectively, all have homes in the state.

The band originated in South Carolina, and the members have maintained their connection to the area, contributing to the local music scene and community.

Dabo Swinney

Dabo Swinney, the head coach of the Clemson University football team, has become an integral part of the South Carolina sports scene.

Swinney, known for leading the Clemson Tigers to multiple national championships, resides in the area and is highly involved in community activities. His commitment to both football excellence and community engagement has made him a beloved figure in the state.

Andie MacDowell

Acclaimed actress Andie MacDowell, known for her roles in films like "Groundhog Day" and "Four Weddings and a Funeral," has a residence in the charming town of Asheville, just across the border in North Carolina, but she often spends time in South Carolina.

MacDowell appreciates the natural beauty and the relaxed atmosphere that the region offers, making it a perfect retreat from her busy Hollywood career.

David Beasley

David Beasley, a politician and former governor of South Carolina, has remained an influential figure in the state's political landscape. Beyond his political career, Beasley has been involved in various humanitarian efforts, including serving as the Executive Director of the United Nations World Food Programme. His commitment to public service has kept him connected to his roots in South Carolina.

Catherine Coleman

Astronaut Catherine "Cady" Coleman, a retired United States Air Force officer and NASA astronaut, has chosen South Carolina as her home. Coleman, who spent over 4,330 hours in space and participated in multiple spacewalks, now contributes to STEM education initiatives in the state. Her decision to live in South Carolina showcases the state's appeal to individuals seeking a balance between adventure and a more grounded lifestyle.

Charlamagne Tha God

Radio personality, television host, and author Lenard Larry McKelvey, professionally known as Charlamagne Tha God, has ties to South Carolina. Born in Moncks Corner, he has risen to prominence as one of the hosts of "The Breakfast Club," a popular syndicated radio show.

Charlamagne Tha God often speaks about his Southern roots and experiences, contributing to the cultural dialogue not only in South Carolina but nationwide.
